data.title: drama
data.meta_description: DRAMA meaning: 1. a type of film or TV programme that tells an exciting and generally serious story, as opposed to…. Learn more.
data.text:
noun

us

Your browser doesn't support HTML5 audio

/ˈdræm.ə/ us

Your browser doesn't support HTML5 audio

/ˈdrɑː.mə/ uk

Your browser doesn't support HTML5 audio

/ˈdrɑː.mə/

drama noun (IN ARTS, MEDIA)

[ C or U ]

a type of movie or TV show that tells an exciting and generally serious story, as opposed to one that is mainly intended to be funny or entertaining:

She stars in a new 12-part drama about a woman recently released from prison.

Who are your favorite TV couples in comedy and drama?

drama series The book was adapted into an HBO drama series.

crime drama The show is essentially a crime drama with a strange twist.

[ C ]

a play written for the theater, for a movie, for television, or for radio:

The interview was later turned into a Broadway drama.

This week we will begin broadcasting a new drama by Patricia Wells.

a historical drama

She studied English and drama at college.

drama critic He's the drama critic for the Times.

More examplesFewer examples

His new series is a raw drama about family life.

Next up is the first episode of a compelling new medical drama set in Copenhagen.

British drama enjoyed a rebirth in the 1950s and 1960s with playwrights like John Osborne, Harold Pinter, and Alan Ayckbourn.

The local drama group is staging a production of the musical "Grease."

The show was a wonderful amalgam of dance, music and drama.

SMART Vocabulary: related words and phrases

You can also find related words, phrases, and synonyms in the topics:

drama noun (EXCITEMENT)

B1 [ C ]

an event or situation, especially an unexpected one, in which there is worry or excitement and usually a lot of action:

We had a little drama last night when the oil in the pan caught fire.

[ U ]

the excitement and energy that is created by a lot of action and arguments:

As a lawyer, he enjoyed the drama of the courtroom.

More examplesFewer examples

Sally always makes a drama out of the smallest of events.

Everybody stopped to watch as the drama of the hostage crisis unfolded on live television.

There was a moment of great drama in Congress today as two protestors ran into the Senate Office Building.

The two teams produced two hours of enjoyable football in a ten-touchdown drama.

Her latest collection of photographs prove that no-one is better at capturing moments of high drama and deep emotion.

(Definition of drama from the Cambridge Advanced Learner's Dictionary & Thesaurus © Cambridge University Press)

drama | Intermediate English

drama

noun

us

Your browser doesn't support HTML5 audio

/ˈdrɑ·mə, ˈdræm·ə/

drama noun (THEATER)

[ C/U ]

a play, esp. a serious one, written to be performed by actors, the writing of plays, or the art of showing plays:

[ C ] She’s been in several television dramas.

[ U ] Arthur Miller, a master of drama, wrote “Death of a Salesman.”

drama noun (EXCITEMENT)

Watching on television was not the same as experiencing the drama of the event in person.

(Definition of drama from the Cambridge Academic Content Dictionary © Cambridge University Press)

Examples of drama

drama

No weather drama either, the next chance of a little light snow or mix will come in about 1 week.

But as the town faces the highest river levels in recorded history, no one can ignore the drama that is unfolding.

It's like a straight-up drama, he plays a cop, it looks so good.

It was a very high drama, spectator-friendly religion.

But that's been the case with romantic dramas.

The producer cuts between the two cameras for visual drama.

This week brings two new high-profile drama series.

The good news is that our writers don't pull any kind of unrealistic hijinks just for the sake of drama.

Despite poor reviews, viewers have largely stuck with the drama about a frazzled mother who works as a cop.

They fret that a longer day will encroach upon after-school sports and drama classes.

Anything related to drama and music seems pretty useless.

The drama was on stage earlier this year.

It's not only one of the best family dramas on television now; it's one of the best family dramas that's ever been on television.

Its tone -- camp and dread; part crime drama, part soap opera, part horror movie -- has never been recreated.

These examples are from corpora and from sources on the web. Any opinions in the examples do not represent the opinion of the Cambridge Dictionary editors or of Cambridge University Press or its licensors.

Collocations with drama

drama

These are words often used in combination with drama.

Click on a collocation to see more examples of it.

audio drama

Pendant is considered part of the growing online community specializing in the revival of audio drama and the subgenre of audio theater.

courtroom drama

The breathless plot developments of the crime and courtroom drama are highly fictionalized allusions to the ponderous workings of the law.

daytime drama

Since then, the award has honored the performances of the entire directing team participating in a form of a daytime drama.
